Dasaratha, anguished, questioned Kaikeyi’s cruel demands, unable to fathom how such a gentle soul could deserve such a fate. He pleaded for Sita to be relieved of the bark garments, arguing that this was not part of any vow he had made. He wished for her to journey to the forest as befitted her royal stature, adorned with jewels and comforts.

In his despair, he admitted that the promise to Kaikeyi, made thoughtlessly, now consumed him with regret. He rebuked Kaikeyi, questioning her relentless pursuit of Sita's suffering when Rama's exile was punishment enough. He recalled the limited promise he had made, far exceeded now by Kaikeyi’s insistence on Sita’s hardship. Despair overcame him, and he fell to the ground, overtaken by grief.

As Rama prepared for his departure, compassionately addressing his father, he beseeched him to care for his mother, Kausalya. He spoke of her virtuous and gentle nature, unaccustomed to the burdens of sorrow. He implored his father, as a protector of his mother, to comfort her during his absence, ensuring her well-being amidst the overwhelming grief.

Rama’s words resonated with reverence, urging his father to act with the might and wisdom of Indra, guarding Kausalya from the despair that threatened to engulf her. His plea was a testament to his enduring love and concern, even as he faced the uncertainties of the forest.

The palace of Ayodhya, once a place of splendor and music, was now shrouded in sorrow. King Dasaratha, upon seeing his beloved son Rama clad in the austere robes of an ascetic, was overwhelmed by grief and fell unconscious, as did his devoted wives. When he regained awareness briefly, the king lamented with a heavy heart, pondering his past deeds, which, he believed, brought about this calamity. The burden of his sorrow was too great; he could neither look at Rama nor speak to him.

In his despair, Dasaratha reflected that life persists despite suffering, for even now, plagued by Kaikeyi's demands and the sight of his son in ascetic garb, his life did not end. He bemoaned Kaikeyi's deceit, which, in her self-serving pursuit, caused immense suffering to many.

With tear-filled eyes, Dasaratha instructed Sumantra to prepare a chariot, adorned in gold, to take Rama out of the city. Obeying the king's orders, Sumantra quickly prepared the horses and chariot, ready for the journey.

As preparations proceeded, Dasaratha called upon the treasury officer to gather garments and ornaments for Sita, Rama’s devoted wife, to last through her years in the forest. The officer dutifully collected the finest items and presented them to Sita. Adorning herself with these sparkling ornaments, Sita shone with the brilliance of the rising sun as she readied to join her husband in exile.

Kausalya, Rama's mother, embraced Sita lovingly and imparted words of wisdom. She spoke of the nature of women who falter in times of hardship, yet extolled the virtues of those who remain steadfast and loyal. A virtuous woman's heart, she said, honors her husband as a god, irrespective of wealth or adversity.

Sita, understanding these sacred teachings, responded with humility and resolve. With folded palms, she assured her mother-in-law of her unwavering devotion to Rama, likening herself to a veena without strings without him. She affirmed that a husband bestows boundless joy unmatched by other familial bonds and vowed never to forsake him.

Kausalya, moved by Sita's words, wept tears of both joy and sorrow. Rama then approached his mother with reverence. He sought to comfort her by promising a swift return, urging her to care for the ailing king. He assured her that fourteen years would pass like a fleeting night and that he would return safely.

Turning to his other three hundred and fifty mothers, Rama, compassionate and virtuous, sought forgiveness for any unintentional wrongs and bade them farewell with heartfelt words.

The women, overwhelmed by grief, wept openly. The once joyful and music-filled palace resonated only with cries of lamentation and sorrow, like a mournful flock of herons.

Thus ended this poignant chapter in the grand and sacred epic of the Ramayana, as composed by the sage Valmiki.

In the heart-wrenching atmosphere of the palace, Sita, Rama, and Lakshmana, with palms joined, reverently touched the feet of King Dasaratha, who was weighed down by deep sorrow. They circumambulated him, marking the beginning of their departure.

Rama, the noble prince of the Raghu dynasty, then took leave of his grieving mother, Kausalya. Lakshmana followed his brother's lead, bowing to Kausalya and then to his own mother, Sumitra. Sumitra, while holding Lakshmana tenderly, kissed his forehead, blessed him, and implored him to remain ever vigilant in his service to Rama during their forest exile. She reminded him that Rama was his guide and refuge, and emphasized the duty of honoring and serving the elder brother. Sumitra urged Lakshmana to see Rama as their father Dasaratha, Sita as herself, and to consider the forest as their home, Ayodhya.

Sumantra, the charioteer skilled in humility and manners, addressed Rama with folded hands, offering to swiftly convey him anywhere he wished. As per Kaikeyi's directive, Rama was to spend fourteen years in exile, and so he prepared to depart, aware that time was of the essence.

Sita, adorned and cheerful, ascended the resplendent chariot, followed by Rama and Lakshmana. Before their departure, Dasaratha provided Sita with clothing and ornaments suited for her days in the forest. He also ensured that weapons and shields were secured for the brothers' protection.

As Sumantra urged the horses, the city of Ayodhya fell into a deep, somber silence, its people shattered by the prince's departure. The streets resounded with the clamor of restless horses, and its citizens—young and old—flocked towards Rama, driven by desperation akin to thirst-driven men seeking water. Clinging to the chariot, they pleaded with Sumantra to slow down, longing for one last glimpse of Rama.

The poignant sight of Kausalya, whose heart seemed made of iron for enduring such sorrow, and Sita, faithfully following Rama like a shadow, moved the people to tears. They admired Lakshmana’s fortune in serving his divine brother and saw their separation from Rama as a tremendous loss.

The city was engulfed in sorrow, tears flowing like rain. As they cried out for Rama, the sound reached the palace, where Dasaratha, surrounded by weeping women, emerged to witness his beloved son’s departure. The once-radiant king appeared dull and broken, like a moon obscured.

Caught between Rama's command to speed away and the people's cries to delay, Sumantra was torn. Yet Rama, unable to bear the sight of his beloved parents trailing behind, urged the charioteer onward. In his heart, he could not endure witnessing their suffering, like an elephant pained by separation.

Kausalya ran behind the chariot, her cries reaching Rama’s ears as she beseeched for his return. Rama, looking back, was forced to reconcile his duty with his love, urging Sumantra to keep going, despite the agonizing pleas.

Despite Dasaratha’s pleas to stop, Rama insisted on departing swiftly, ensuring Sumantra would bear no blame for his choice. As the king watched his son fade from view, his heart was burdened by the weight of their separation. His ministers, recognizing the futility of prolonging their grief, gently advised him against excessive mourning.

Broken but resigned, Dasaratha stood, his gaze fixed on the horizon where his son had disappeared, held fast by the bonds of duty and love.

As Rama, the foremost of men, prepared to depart with folded hands, a heartrending cry arose from the inner chambers of the palace. The lament of the women echoed through the halls, their grief palpable as they mourned the loss of their protector and refuge. Rama had been a beacon of hope for the defenseless, the weak, and the downtrodden. Now, the anguished question lingered: Where is such a protector going?

Rama, the effulgent and magnanimous one, known for his restraint and compassion, who quelled anger and shared in others' sorrows, was revered almost as much as his mother Kausalya. Where was he going now? The king, tormented and compelled by the demands of Kaikeyi, had sent Rama to the forest. This protector, dear to the world and embodiment of truth and righteousness, was being banished. The city lamented: how could the king make such a senseless decision?

The cries of the king's wives were like the mournful lowing of cows separated from their calves. The wailing from the palace deepened the king's sorrow, already heavy from parting with his beloved son.

In Ayodhya, the world seemed suspended in grief. The sacred fire of rituals was neglected, meals went uncooked, and daily life came to a stop as the sun set on a city in mourning. Elephants dropped their food, cows refrained from nursing their calves, and even mothers turned away from their children.

The heavens themselves mirrored the turmoil. The constellation Trishanku, along with Mars, Jupiter, and Mercury, ominously surrounded the moon. Stars lost their luster, planets dimmed, and smoke shrouded the skies.

As Rama departed, dark clouds loomed like ocean waves driven by violent winds, casting a shadow over the city. Nothing shone in the heavens, and Ayodhya was enveloped in sorrow. The people, overwhelmed with grief, lost interest in life's pleasures and sustenance.

The streets, teeming with people on the brink of despair, wore a mantle of tears. No joy lingered in faces, only a shared sorrow for the absence of their lord, King Dasaratha.

The land held its breath; the breeze turned harsh, the moon lost its charm, and the sun withheld its warmth. Relationships grew distant as thoughts turned solely to Rama, leaving friends, family, and loved ones forsaken in their affliction.

Ayodhya, without Rama's magnanimity, resembled a world devoid of its mighty Indra, trembling in fear and sorrow under the chaotic din of restless horses, elephants, and warriors. Such was the state of the world as it mourned the departure of its beloved prince.

As the chariot carrying Rama to the forest departed, the dust stirred by its wheels lingered in the air. King Dasaratha, the noble patriarch of the Ikshvaku dynasty, remained rooted, his eyes fixed on the retreating figure of his beloved son. His heart rose and fell, yearning for one more glimpse, until even the dust vanished from sight, leaving him desolate. Overwhelmed by sorrow, the king collapsed to the ground, his spirit crushed by grief.

Kausalya, his devoted queen, gently grasped Dasaratha's right hand, while Kaikeyi, the mother of Bharata, reached for his left. In a voice trembling with pain, the righteous king turned to Kaikeyi, rejecting her touch. He saw only betrayal in her actions, severing the ties of marriage and kinship they once shared. Filled with bitterness, he renounced her and, with a heavy heart, cursed that even Bharata’s offerings would not bring him peace in the afterlife.

Kausalya, though weary from her own sorrow, helped the king back to his feet and slowly guided him to the palace. Dasaratha, tormented by memories of seeing Rama dressed in ascetic robes, felt as though he had committed an unforgivable sin. He gazed back repeatedly, seeking the path of the chariot, yet Rama was no longer visible, leaving Dasaratha as dim as the eclipsed sun.

The king's lamentations filled the air as he imagined Rama, once pampered and cherished, now lying beneath trees with only stones for pillows. He pictured the regal visage of his son, covered in dust and rising wearily from the ground, observed by the wild denizens of the forest. Thoughts of Sita, the delicate princess enduring the harsh wilderness, haunted him, as did her fear of the forest's fierce creatures.

Dasaratha's voice quivered with sorrow and futility. He turned to Kaikeyi, declaring her wish fulfilled, as he resigned to ruling a kingdom devoid of his beloved Rama. Entering Ayodhya, the once vibrant city seemed a shadow of its former self. Streets lay deserted, marketplaces were shuttered, and temples closed as the people, weakened by grief, wandered aimlessly. The king entered his palace like a sun swallowed by clouds, heavy with the absence of Rama, Lakshmana, and Sita.

The palace, echoing in its emptiness, felt as desolate as a lake bereft of life. Dasaratha, his spirit broken, called out in desperation for Rama, lamenting the fortune of those who would one day witness his return. In the stillness of the night, each moment stretched like death. He confided to Kausalya that his vision, once filled with Rama, was now clouded. Her touch was the only solace for his troubled heart.

Kausalya, sitting beside him, sighed deeply, her sorrow uncontainable. In that somber embrace of shared grief, their hearts anchored to the memory of Rama, they endured the night, lamenting the separation that shadowed their lives.

Overwhelmed by sorrow at the departure of her beloved son, Kausalya gazed at the weary king lying on the couch. Her heart was heavy as she spoke, lamenting how Kaikeyi's deceitful actions mirrored those of a serpent releasing its venom onto the finest of men, Rama. Now, Kaikeyi moved freely, as if reborn, a cunning serpent unburdened by its old skin, fulfilled and happy with her desires achieved. Yet, Kausalya foresaw ongoing fear as Kaikeyi, like a dangerous serpent dwelling within, would continue to instill terror.

The thought crossed Kausalya's mind that it might have been better to offer her son as Kaikeyi's servant, allowing him to remain in their home, living humbly yet nearby. The decision of the king to yield to Kaikeyi's whims had sent Rama away, akin to sacrificers errantly gifting offerings meant for gods to demons on sacred nights.

As Rama ventured into the forest with Sita and Lakshmana, Kausalya imagined her son, noble and strong, moving with a majestic grace likened to that of a regal elephant. The uncertainty of forest life plagued her, pondering how her children, who had known only comfort, would endure harsh conditions with nothing but fruits and roots to sustain them.

She yearned for the day when her sorrow would cease, envisioning the joyful moment when Rama would return home, accompanied by his wife and brother, to a jubilant Ayodhya adorned with raised banners. The city, she imagined, would swell with joy, celebrating the return of its beloved princes like the ocean under a full moon.

She longed to witness Rama entering Ayodhya in a chariot, Sita before him, embodying a dignified procession. The people would shower them with blessings, scattering parched grains on their path. She envisioned them adorned with earrings, brandishing weapons high, like twin peaks towering in majesty.

Kausalya dreamed of them enjoying the city's hospitality, young girls presenting them with flowers and fruits. Her mind lingered on the image of Rama, wise beyond his years and glowing with a divine brilliance, returning playfully to her as a young child might.

Reflecting on her despair, she believed that such separation from her son must be retribution for past wrongs. Her soul felt torn by Kaikeyi's actions, likening herself to a cow separated from its calf by a lion's cruelty. Without Rama, the adept and virtuous, she felt life slipping away, her world dimmed by grief's oppressive heat.

Thus, in the anguish of a mother separated forcibly from her cherished son, Kausalya's lamentation echoed through the heart of Ayodhya, marking the close of this chapter in the sacred Ramayana.

Amidst her lamentations, the virtuous Sumitra addressed Kausalya with words imbued with wisdom and righteousness. "Noble lady," she began, "your son Rama, greatest among men and endowed with every virtue, has renounced the kingdom to honor his truthful father's words. This adherence to the path of the wise promises everlasting results in the world to come. Grieve not for such a son.

"Your noble son, accompanied by his brother Lakshmana, who is compassionate and noble, walks the righteous path. Even Sita, accustomed to comforts, chose to embrace the hardships of forest life to stand by him. With righteousness and truth as his wealth, Rama's fame will resonate throughout the world.

"Fear not, for the Sun dares not scorch Rama with its rays, and a gentle breeze will attend to him in every season. By night, the Moon comforts him with cool beams, like a father’s gentle embrace.

"Rama, brave and heroic, possesses divine weapons bequeathed by Viswamitra after defeating Subahu. He will dwell fearlessly in the forest, confident in his prowess, as if he were in a royal palace. His enemies, mere targets for his arrows, pose no threat to a kingdom under his eventual rule.

"Upon his return, Rama will regain his kingdom, shining with splendor and strength. He is the light of the Sun, fire of the fire, and master among masters. Whether in the forest or the city, his virtues remain undiminished.

"When Rama, adorned in robes of kusha and bark, left Ayodhya, its people wept for the godlike prince. Yet what can be impossible for him, accompanied by Sita, the embodiment of fortune, and protected by Lakshmana, the best of archers?

"I assure you, Kausalya, that Rama will return from exile. In time, you will witness him touch your feet with reverence, and tears of joy will replace your sorrow. Await the day when he, like the rising Moon, returns with Sita and Lakshmana.

"O sinless queen, forsake your grief. With a son like Rama, steadfast in virtue, what cause is there for sadness? Soon, you will shed tears of joy, seeing your son bow to you in reverence.

"Rama, a bestower of boons, will soon press your feet with his gentle hands, and you will see him surrounded by friends, drenched in your joyful tears, like rain upon a mountain."

Sumitra, having spoken skillfully and with a cheerful disposition, fell silent, leaving Kausalya consoled. Her sorrow, like an autumn cloud holding little rain, faded away.

Thus concludes the chapter of the holy Ramayana by Sage Valmiki, with its timeless narrative of virtue and devotion.

As Rama, esteemed for his unwavering adherence to truth, set forth towards the forest, the devoted people of Ayodhya could not bear to part with him. Despite his insistence, King Dasaratha and his retinue of loyal friends steadfastly followed him, unwilling to return. To the townspeople, Rama was cherished as dearly as the full Moon.

Rama's determination to fulfill his father’s vow was resolute, despite the heart-wrenching pleas from his subjects. He gazed upon them with the affection of a parent, as if to imprint their image upon his heart. He implored them gently to transfer the devotion they showed him to his brother Bharata. Bharata, he assured, was as virtuous and wise as he was youthful, capable of guiding them with care and strength, ready to implement all beneficial actions.

Heeding Rama’s words, the people’s desire for him to rule only grew stronger, like vines clinging ever tighter around the noble trunk from which they sprouted. As Rama, alongside Lakshmana and Sita, drew the hearts of Ayodhya into his orbit, the city dwellers, tear-stricken and hollowed by sorrow, could not let him depart with their blessings, yet without their tears.

Elderly brahmins, venerable in age and wisdom, beseeched Rama from a distance, their voices frail yet firm. They pleaded with the horses pulling his chariot to turn back, to ensure their master would not advance further away from them, away from his rightful place.

Seeing their poignant entreaties, Rama dismounted from his chariot, choosing to proceed on foot with Sita and Lakshmana by his side. Such was his compassion, that he would not leave the brahmins to struggle along the path behind him.

Determined, the brahmins declared their intent to accompany Rama into the forest, carrying with them the sacrificial fires and umbrellas acquired through their sacred Vajapeya rites. They offered these as protection from the sun's scorching rays, insisting their path lay with his, an unwavering testament to their loyalty.

They spoke of the Vedas residing in their hearts, a wealth greater than any, while their wives, guardians of fidelity, would remain behind. Their resolve to follow him was set, undeterred by any countermand.

As they implored, with heads bowed by age, for Rama to consider returning, the scene transformed into one of universal lamentation. The trees, held firm by their roots, seemed to weep at their inability to follow. Birds forsook their natural pursuits, imploring Rama through their silent vigil.

Even the gentle river Tamasa seemed to beseech him to return. Amidst this tapestry of sorrow, Sumantra unyoked the weary horses, allowing them a brief respite by the riverbank. He tended to their needs, letting them enjoy the cool water and graze nearby, as preparations were made for the journey ahead.

Thus, the moment marked a poignant pause in their passage, wrapped in the profound melancholy of parting and the enduring love of a people entwined in the virtues of their prince, Rama.

Rama, the noble scion of the Raghus, found solace on the serene banks of the Tamasa River amidst the unfolding night of their exile. Turning to his devoted brother Lakshmana, he spoke gently, acknowledging the beginning of their journey away from Ayodhya. He urged Lakshmana not to harbor longings for their past life, reassuring him with words of affection and purpose.

As twilight descended, the surrounding forest was filled with the calls of returning wild animals and birds, seeking refuge in their natural abodes. Rama reflected upon the state of Ayodhya, imagining the sorrow-laden hearts of its people and the lamentations echoing for their beloved princes and the virtuous king, Dasaratha.

His thoughts turned to their parents, and he worried for their well-being, fearing that grief might blind them to the world. Yet, he found comfort in the steadfastness and virtue of Bharata, confident that his brother would console their parents with wisdom and love.

Deep gratitude filled Rama’s heart towards Lakshmana, who chose to accompany him on this arduous path. Rama acknowledged the essential support Lakshmana would provide, particularly for Sita’s safety. Despite the bounty of the forest, Rama chose to sustain himself with only water for the evening, signaling his commitment to the ascetic life they embraced.

With the setting sun, Sumantra, their loyal charioteer, meticulously cared for the horses and prepared a humble bed of leaves. Reverent in his duties, Sumantra performed his evening rites before ensuring the comfort of his noble charges.

As Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana settled into their makeshift resting place, Lakshmana remained vigilant, praising Rama’s virtues to Sumantra throughout the night. The hours passed peacefully until the dawn heralded a new day.

Upon waking, Rama observed the dedicated citizens of Ayodhya, who in their devotion had forsaken the comforts of home to stay close to their exiled prince. He realized their determination might lead them to unimaginable sacrifice; hence, he resolved to leave quietly to relieve them of such a burden.

Conveying his intentions to Lakshmana, who readily agreed, Rama instructed Sumantra to prepare the chariot for a swift departure. As the chariot was harnessed, Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana crossed the swirling current of the Tamasa River, embarking on an auspicious and reassuring path through the forest.

To protect the citizens from following them, Rama devised a strategy. He instructed Sumantra to mislead the people by initially taking a northerly route before veering back, a maneuver meant to conceal their true path. Sumantra executed the plan with skill, returning with the chariot ready for the continued journey.

With the first light of day, the companions set forth, their chariot guided by Sumantra’s skilled hands. Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana journeyed onward, leaving behind the comfort of familiarity, embracing the uncertainty of exile with courage and resolve. Thus, their journey into the heart of the forest continued, led by duty and the promise of righteousness.

As the night began to retreat and the first light of dawn emerged, the citizens of Ayodhya awoke to a shocking emptiness—the absence of Rama, the noble scion of the Raghu dynasty. Overcome by an intense sorrow, they found themselves in a haze, their hearts heavy and their senses numbed by grief.

Desperately, they searched in all directions, hoping against hope to find even the slightest sign of Rama. But their efforts were in vain. The faces of these high-minded citizens, shadowed with despair, mirrored their deep anguish as they voiced their lamentations.

"Curse this sleep that stole our awareness!" they cried. "How is it that we cannot now see the broad-chested, mighty-armed Rama? How could he, who never leaves a service unrepaid, abandon his devoted people and wander into exile?"

Reflecting on the guidance and protection Rama had always provided, much like a father to his children, they could not fathom his departure to the forest. "Without him," they insisted, "life holds no meaning. We might as well succumb to death's eternal embrace."

In their despair, they contemplated building a pyre from the plentiful dry wood, thinking to immolate themselves, for living without Rama seemed unbearable.

"What shall we tell others?" they pondered. "How can we explain that we, who set out with the noble Rama, have returned without him? Our city’s women, children, and aged will be plunged into desolation when they see us return alone."

Their cries echoed like those of cows bereft of their calves—voices raised in poignant, lamenting chorus. They followed the trail of Rama's chariot for a short while, but soon, the tracks vanished, and they were swallowed once more by sorrow. Dejected, they murmured among themselves, "Fate has deceived us. What are we to do now?"

Resigned and weary, the virtuous folk turned back toward Ayodhya. As the city came into view, their hearts were further pierced with pain. Tears flowed freely, their sorrow as vast as the ocean. The vibrant Ayodhya of their memories now seemed drab and lifeless, its essence diminished, like a river stripped of its snakes by Garuda.

The people entered their once joyous city, finding it akin to a sky without its beloved moon or an ocean drained of its waters. Bereft of joy and consumed by grief, they stumbled into their opulent homes. Even when they gazed upon their kin and fellow citizens, they saw not familiar faces but strangers, their eyes blinded by loss.

The city of Ayodhya was enveloped in a pall of sorrow as its people returned from bidding farewell to the noble prince, Rama. Their hearts were heavy, eyes brimming with tears, for they could not bear the thought of life without him. With spirits crushed, they moved as though their very life force had been drained away.

At home, surrounded by their families, they broke down in tears, a torrent of grief washing over them. Joy seemed to have vanished from their lives, and activities that once filled their days with purpose now appeared meaningless. The bustling market, once full of life, lay dormant; merchants withheld their goods, the liveliness of trade reduced to a mere shadow of its former self. Even the simple act of preparing a meal was neglected, as the people lost interest in the mundane aspects of daily life.

The joys of wealth and the happiness of welcoming a newborn son were lost on them. In every household, the voices of women echoed with anguish as they lamented the absence of Rama, questioning the very worth of their possessions, their families, and their homes without the presence of the beloved prince.

Lakshmana, in their eyes, was truly blessed to accompany Rama and Sita. They mused on how the forests and rivers were fortunate to be graced by Rama's presence, delighting in how such natural beauties would now serve as his sanctuary, offering their bounty and splendor as a tribute to the scion of the Raghu dynasty.

The trees would bloom with vibrant flowers, their fragrance wafting through the air to welcome Rama, while mountains and rivers, with their crystal-clear waters and lush surroundings, would embrace him warmly. In these wild places, Rama would find neither fear nor disrespect.

The women of Ayodhya spoke fervently, urging their husbands to follow Rama before he journeyed too far, swearing that they would rather serve Sita in the forest than remain in a city devoid of hope and joy. They feared the reign of Kaikeyi, her actions having brought disgrace upon their land and cast a shadow over the future. Under her rule, they foresaw a kingdom plunged into ruin, as they lamented the misfortune that had befallen them.

The specter of a world where Rama was not present seemed unbearable. They envisioned him, a majestic figure with a presence as calming as the full moon, transforming the forests with his grace and truthfulness. To them, Rama was not merely a prince, but a beacon of righteousness and strength.

As night descended upon the city, Ayodhya was shrouded in a somber gloom. The fires of sacrifice extinguished, holy recitations ceased, and a heavy silence pervaded. Markets remained closed, and the city, devoid of its usual vibrancy, appeared like a starless sky.

The sound of weeping filled the air, as the women of the city mourned for Rama with an intensity rivaling the loss of a son or brother. His absence left Ayodhya without its music, dance, and celebration, reducing the once-glorious city to a shadow of its former self, like an ocean with its waters drained away.

Thus ended a day of deep lamentation in Ayodhya, the echoes of sorrow lingering as a testament to the love and loyalty inspired by Rama, the cherished son of the Raghu dynasty.

Recollecting his father's command, Rama, noblest among men, journeyed through the night with purpose. As the auspicious night yielded to the gentle glimmer of dawn, he completed his morning rituals and found himself at the frontier of his homeland.

As he traveled, he observed villages graced by the plow and forests vibrant with blooms. He listened to the murmurs of villagers, their voices a mix of sorrow and outrage, and though his horses were swift, it all seemed strangely slow to Rama.

The villagers spoke bitterly of their king, who, overtaken by passion, had succumbed to the manipulations of the heartless Kaikeyi. They lamented her cruel actions, which had sent Rama, righteous and wise, into exile. They marveled at her audacity, breaking all decorum in her pursuit of selfish desires.

Their concerns extended to Sita, the cherished daughter of Janaka, wondering how she would bear such hardships. They pitied King Dasaratha, who appeared willing to forsake his blameless son, adored by the people.

These murmurs followed Rama as he crossed the boundaries of Kosala, his mind absorbing the anguish of his subjects. He then traversed the sacred waters of the Vedasruti and journeyed south, where the esteemed sage Agastya resided.

Along the cool, grazing lands by the river Gomati, Rama continued, eventually crossing where it flowed into the sea. Pressing onward with his swift steeds, he crossed the river Syandika, alive with the calls of peacocks and swans.

Rama, ever graceful, pointed out the vast, encircling lands of kingdoms once granted to his ancestor Ikshvaku by the great emperor Manu. With a voice as soothing as an intoxicated swan, he spoke to his charioteer of his longing for home.

He dreamed of returning to his parents, of hunting in the lush forests by the Sarayu River—a royal sport enjoyed by kings and sages alike. Yet, it was not the hunt that filled his heart with yearning.

As he shared these musings in a mellifluous voice, Rama continued on his journey, his thoughts drifting between duty and desire, past and future. Thus unfolded another chapter in the epic tale of the Ramayana, the timeless saga of virtue and destiny.

Having left the grand and verdant kingdom of Kosala behind, Rama, the sagacious elder brother of Lakshmana, turned to face Ayodhya. With folded palms, he bade farewell to the city, acknowledging it as the finest among cities, ruled by the noble Kakutstha dynasty. He expressed his resolve, vowing to return once his exile was complete and his filial duties to his father, King Dasaratha, fulfilled, hoping to reunite with his parents and the revered city again.

Tears filled Rama’s copper-red eyes as he addressed the villagers who had gathered to see him off. With gratitude, he acknowledged their kindness and urged them to return to their duties, suggesting it was not fitting to prolong their sorrow. The villagers, overwhelmed by emotion, paid homage to Rama. They circled him in reverence before standing aside, their hearts heavy as they witnessed him disappear from their sight like the sun setting at dusk.

As Rama, the best among men, traversed the splendid land of Kosala, he noted its charm—the sacrificial altars and sacred posts, pleasure gardens, mango groves, and water-filled tanks. The kingdom was rich in cattle, wealth, and grains, inhabited by generous and contented people who lived without fear and resonated with the sacred sounds of Vedic recitations. As he traveled through this prosperous realm, delightful gardens fit for kings lined his path.

Eventually, Rama arrived at the sacred Ganga, whose pure waters flowed gracefully, unmarred by moss and revered by sages. The holy river, adorned with noble hermitages, was a playground for nymphs who frolicked in its serene lakes. It served as a gathering place for gods, celestial beings, and kindred spirits. Known as 'Devapadmini,' the Ganga's waters were adorned with celestial lotuses, and her banks and hillsides provided pleasure-gardens for divine beings.

The Ganga, with her laughter-like ripples and foamy smiles, danced through whirlpools. At times, she flowed serenely, at others, she roared fiercely with her powerful currents. Her banks resonated with the calls of swans, cranes, and geese, mingling with the melodic chirping of passionate birds. Lush trees stood adorned as if with garlands, and the shimmering waters were dotted with lilies and lotuses.

The river, a symbol of purity, sparkled like a transparent gem. Her banks were a riot of fruits, flowers, and tender leaves, inhabited by birds, Brahmins, and wildlife. Majestic elephants, intoxicated and mighty, paraded the forests along her edges.

Reaching the city of Srngaberapura on the banks of this divine river, Rama listened to the cries of kraunchas and herons. He stood awed by the Ganga, the sinless river flowing from the feet of Lord Vishnu, a testament to the penance of Bhagiratha and the grace of Lord Shiva’s matted locks.

Observing the river's vibrant waves and whirlpools, the great chariot-warrior turned to Sumantra and said, "We shall spend the night here," embracing the tranquil embrace of this sacred waterside.

In the serene stillness of the forest, the noble Guha, chieftain of the Nishadas and devoted friend of Rama, observed the unwavering vigilance of Lakshmana. His heart swelled with admiration for the young prince who, for his brother's sake, chose sleepless watchfulness over rest. Tenderly he spoke, offering a comfortable bed prepared for Lakshmana, urging him to rest. Guha assured him that he and his people were accustomed to hardship and could keep watch, ensuring Rama’s safety.

Guha declared his deep devotion to Rama, stating that there was no one dearer to him in the world. He pledged his life's ambition for dharma and prosperity, solely through Rama’s grace. His kinsmen, armed and ever vigilant, surrounded the sacred trio, vowing to guard them from any harm that might lurk in the wilderness.

Lakshmana, with a gentle yet firm resolve, expressed his gratitude to Guha. He acknowledged the impeccable protection offered by the righteous Guha, but could not conceive of resting as long as Rama, the beloved son of Dasaratha, slept on the earth's bare ground. It was unthinkable for him to enjoy any comfort while Rama, who stood undefeatable against gods and demons alike, lay humbly on the forest floor beside Sita.

Reflecting on Rama's noble birth and the austere penances of their father, Dasaratha, Lakshmana voiced fears of impending doom. He foresaw that the king would not survive the anguish of separation from his cherished son, predicting a sorrowful desolation of their homeland.

Lakshmana lamented over the plight of the royal household, fearing for the lives of their mothers, especially the grieving Kausalya. He envisioned the flourishing city of Ayodhya falling into mourning, its vibrant life decimated by the king’s demise. Yet, he acknowledged those who would bear witness to Dasaratha’s end as fortunate to serve in his final rites.

In his sorrow, Lakshmana pondered whether they shall ever return to the splendor of Ayodhya and reunite with the noble king, thus fulfilling the exile’s vows alongside Rama, steadfast to his promise. As the night waned in deep mourning shared with Guha, the chieftain absorbed Lakshmana's lament. Tears flowed plentifully from Guha's eyes, stirred by the heartfelt recounting of Rama’s tale, as he grieved with the intensity of an elephant in pain.

Thus, the passage of night dissolved into dawn, imbued with earnest friendship and shared sorrow, as nature’s cycle ushered in another day of their long exile.

As night yielded to the first light of dawn, Rama, the illustrious scion of the Ikshvaku dynasty, addressed his brother Lakshmana, who bore auspicious marks. "Lakshmana," said Rama, "the holy night has passed, and the birds herald the coming day. We must cross the swift Ganga and continue our journey."

Obediently, Lakshmana, ever the bringer of joy to his brother, summoned Guha, the king of the Nishadas, and Sumantra, the devoted charioteer. Guha, receiving Rama’s request, directed his ministers to prepare a strong and auspicious boat, equipped with adept helmsmen to navigate the river with ease. Upon completion, Guha reverently informed Rama of the boat’s readiness.

Rama expressed his gratitude, instructing Guha to carefully place their belongings aboard. Armed and ready, Rama and Lakshmana, along with Sita, approached the sacred river. Sumantra, faithful and distressed, questioned his role, but Rama, with gentle assurance, relieved him of duty, urging him to return to Ayodhya and serve King Dasaratha.

Rama, wise and compassionate, gave instructions to Sumantra on conveying messages to the grieving hearts in Ayodhya—his father King Dasaratha, his mother Kausalya, and his brother Bharata. He spoke with foresight about the inevitable passing of time and their eventual return after fourteen long years.

Sumantra, heartbroken by the impending separation, pleaded with Rama, expressing his inability to return to Ayodhya without him. He lamented the sorrow that an empty chariot would bring to the people of the city, who had witnessed Rama’s departure in it. Tearfully, he begged to accompany Rama into exile, willing even to relinquish all worldly and heavenly pleasures for the honor of serving him in the forest.

In response, Rama, recognizing Sumantra’s devotion, explained the necessity of his return. Sumantra’s presence in Ayodhya would confirm to Queen Kaikeyi that Rama had indeed embarked on his forest exile, fulfilling the king’s promise. Rama’s intent was clear—he wished for Kaikeyi to embrace the kingdom under her son Bharata’s rule without any shadow of doubt.

Rama next turned to Guha, addressing practicalities of governance, and after assurances of vigilant rule, took leave of his friend. Prepared for the crossing, Rama, Lakshmana, and Sita boarded the boat. As they pushed off from the shore, Rama recited mantras for safety, and the boat navigated towards the distant bank under the skilled guidance of the helmsmen.

In the middle of the river, Sita, with hands folded in prayer, invoked the blessings of the sacred Ganga. She sought protection and vowed offerings upon their safe return, expressing her hope that Rama would fulfill all ordained duties and safely reclaim his rightful place in Ayodhya.

After reaching the opposite shore, Rama advised vigilance as they ventured deeper into the unfamiliar forest. Sensing the impending challenges, he instructed Lakshmana to lead with Sita close behind, while he took the rear, ensuring their mutual safety.

With resolve marking his stride, Rama proceeded, leaving behind the grieving Sumantra, who watched until Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana disappeared from view. Crossing into the prosperous lands of Vatsa, Rama and Lakshmana hunted for sustenance. As twilight enveloped them, they rested under the sheltering boughs of a tree, ending another day in their cherished journey through the wilderness.

Thus concluded this poignant progression in their exile, a testament to duty, sacrifice, and unwavering devotion.

As the sun dipped behind the horizon, Rama and Lakshmana found themselves at the foot of a towering tree. Evening had arrived, and Rama, the embodiment of virtue and calm, offered prayers to the setting sun. Turning to Lakshmana, his devoted brother, Rama spoke with a serene assurance, noting that they would spend the night without the presence of Sumantra, away from human habitation. Despite the circumstances, he urged Lakshmana not to worry.

Rama emphasized the need for vigilance, remarking how their sleepless watchfulness would ensure Sita's safety. He accepted the simplicity of their situation, intent on making the best of what they had. Laying down on the earth, Rama, who was accustomed to luxuries, voiced his thoughts to Lakshmana.

He contemplated the Maharaja's troubled slumber that night, contrasting it with Kaikeyi's satisfaction in achieving her desires. Rama pondered the impact of Bharata's arrival, concerned that Kaikeyi might drive the king to despair for the sake of power. Reflecting on the king's condition, Rama lamented how passion often overshadowed righteousness and wealth.

Rama questioned how even an illiterate person could forsake a devoted son, as his father had done. He foresaw Bharata enjoying the kingdom's prosperity alone while King Dasaratha, aged and forlorn, was deprived of his presence. Rama remarked on Dasaratha's abandonment of dharma and artha, attributing his downfall to indulgence in pleasure.

He speculated that Kaikeyi's presence in their lives seemed destined for the king's ruin, his own exile, and Bharata's ascension. Rama feared that Kaikeyi, intoxicated by fortune, might oppress Kausalya and Sumitra. Concerned for his mother Sumitra, he urged Lakshmana to return to Ayodhya to protect her, while he ventured into the Dandaka forest with Sita.

Rama reflected on destiny, pondering whether his mother Kausalya was thwarted by past actions. Once nurtured for happiness, she now faced suffering due to his separation from her. In sorrow, Rama cursed his inability to serve his mother, noting how even her pet birds brought more joy than he could in these circumstances.

Rama lamented her misfortune, imagining her drowning in grief due to their separation. Despite his prowess, Rama refrained from resorting to force, driven by his commitment to righteousness. 

As tears filled his eyes, Rama sat in silence, his lamentation a mere whisper in the vast, lonely forest. Lakshmana, steadfast as ever, comforted his brother, likening the city of Ayodhya to a moonless night without Rama’s presence.

Lakshmana urged Rama to abandon despair, reminding him of the bond they shared. Together with Sita, they could not bear to live a moment apart from him. Lakshmana professed his loyalty, valuing Rama above all else, even heaven.

With gentle reassurance, Rama listened to Lakshmana’s earnest words. He granted his brother leave to remain at his side in the forest for the entire period of fourteen years, adhering to the forest’s austerities.

Thus, the brothers, mighty and resolute like lions of the Raghu race, embraced their fate with courage and harmony, dwelling fearlessly in the heart of the forest.

Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana spent a serene night beneath the canopy of a grand tree. As dawn broke, they continued their journey into the profound depths of the forest. Their path led them to enchanting landscapes they had never before seen, moving steadily toward the convergence of the Yamuna and the sacred Bhagirathi Ganga.

As they walked, surrounded by a variety of trees, Rama pointed to a column of smoke rising near Prayaga, suspecting an ascetic’s hermitage lay nearby. Approaching the confluence of the rivers, they were greeted by the sounds of rushing waters and signs of forestdwellers. Logs lay ready, cut by those who subsisted on the forest’s bounty, signaling their nearness to the hermitage of Sage Bharadwaja.

By evening, the trio reached the sage’s abode. The presence of Rama startled the deer and birds, but soon the two brothers, with Sita following, stood respectfully at the entrance, wishing to meet the sage. Inside, they found the venerable Bharadwaja, surrounded by his disciples, a sage who had attained great spiritual insight through rigorous austerity and devotion.

Rama introduced himself and his companions—the devoted Sita, his esteemed consort, and his steadfast brother, Lakshmana. He explained their exile and their commitment to a life sustained by the forest’s provisions.

Pleased, Bharadwaja welcomed them with traditional hospitality, offering water and food from roots and fruits, providing a place for rest. As they sat in the hermit's sanctuary, Bharadwaja spoke warmly to Rama of his long journey and the unjust exile he had endured.

The sage suggested they might find comfort near the river confluence, but Rama, considerate of Sita’s needs for solace, expressed concern that the people from nearby villages might disturb their peace there. Bharadwaja then described a more secluded haven, the sacred mountain Chitrakuta, resplendent with nature’s beauty and tranquility.

Rama listened to the sage’s counsel, envisioning the serene mountain where they could live in harmony with the forest’s creatures and natural wonders. Bharadwaja extended his hospitality through the night, sharing stories that captivated and comforted them.

With the first light of dawn, Rama respectfully sought the sage’s permission to leave. Bharadwaja affirmed their journey to Chitrakuta, filled with the richness of nature, its harmony echoed by joyous birds, majestic elephants, and gentle deer. Here, he assured, Rama and Sita would find joy and peace among the sacred groves and echoing songs of the forest.

Thus guided by the wisdom of Bharadwaja, Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana prepared to journey on, their hearts uplifted by the promise of new beginnings at Chitrakuta.

After spending a night under the starry sky, the noble princes, Rama and Lakshmana, offered their respects to the venerable sage Bharadwaja. With hearts full of gratitude and determination, they set forth towards the revered Mount Chitrakuta.

As they prepared to leave, the great sage, exuding a fatherly warmth, blessed them for a safe journey. He followed the brothers like a loving guardian bidding farewell to his children. In a voice laced with wisdom, Bharadwaja spoke to Rama, whose strength lay in truth and righteousness.

He guided them to the confluence of the sacred rivers Ganga and Yamuna, urging them to proceed alongside the westward flow of the Yamuna, known as the Kalindi. Upon reaching the swift-moving river, they were to find an ancient spot on its banks, where they could construct a raft to cross the daughter of the Sun.

Bharadwaja described a magnificent banyan tree, its dark, lush leaves whispering secrets of the ages past. Inhabited by siddhas, this tree was a place of invocations and blessings. He instructed Sita to offer her prayers there for her well-being and for the fulfillment of Rama’s vow.

At this sacred tree, they could either rest or continue their journey. Just a bit further lay a verdant forest filled with Palasas, badaris, and bamboos, a path the sage himself had traversed many times. It was a path of beauty and tranquility, unharmed by the ravages of forest fires.

With a humble heart, Rama acknowledged the sage's guidance, expressing his gratitude and bidding him farewell. As Bharadwaja returned to his abode, Rama turned to Lakshmana, feeling fortunate for the sage's benevolence.

Conversing joyfully, the brothers advanced towards the river, with Sita walking gracefully ahead. Upon reaching the surging Kalindi, they pondered the best way to cross. Crafting a sturdy raft from logs and bamboo, they spread fragrant Ushira roots and made a comfortable seat for Sita using reeds and Jambu branches.

Rama, tender and loving, assisted Sita, the embodiment of grace, onto the float. Alongside her, he placed robes, ornaments, a spade, a basket, and their trusted weapons. With careful guidance, the valiant sons of Dasaratha led the raft across the river.

In the river's embrace, as waters swirled beneath them, Sita offered her reverent salutations, praying for safety and the fulfillment of vows. She promised offerings of cows and wine upon Rama’s victorious return to Ayodhya.

With prayers whispered to the wind, they reached the southern bank of the Yamuna. Leaving the raft behind, they ventured towards a cool, dark banyan tree, its leaves swaying gently as if acknowledging their journey.

At this ancient sentinel, Sita paused, offering her salutations and praying for her husband’s success and the joy of reuniting with Kausalya and Sumitra. With graceful devotion, she circled the tree, her every gesture sacred and sincere.

Guided by her faith and their shared purpose, Rama instructed Lakshmana to walk ahead with Sita, while he followed, vigilant with weapons. He urged Lakshmana to gather any fruit or flower Sita desired, her happiness a guiding light for them.

Journeying together through the forest, Sita marveled at unfamiliar trees and blossoms. Lakshmana, attentive to her delight, collected vibrant plants and flowers, presenting them to her with affection.

The river's rhythmic flow, echoing with swans and cranes, filled Sita with joy. As they journeyed a little further, the brothers hunted deer for sustenance, their spirits intertwined with the forest’s vibrant life.

Eventually, they reached a picturesque plateau along the riverbank, alive with the melodies of peacocks and the calls of monkeys and elephants. It was here, amidst nature's grandeur, that they chose to make their temporary home.

As the night slipped away, the dawn's first light embraced the forest. Rama, the Delight of the Raghus, softly stirred Lakshmana from his slumber. "Listen to the morning songs of the forest birds, O son of Sumitra," he urged, "It is time for us to set forth."

Lakshmana, awakened by his brother's gentle call, shrugged off sleep, shaking away the journey's fatigue. With renewed energy, they all rose, touching the river's auspicious waters, and began their path towards the serene mount Chitrakuta, just as the sage had directed.

Early in the morning, Rama set out with Lakshmana and addressed Sita, whose eyes were as splendid as lotus petals. "O daughter of Videha," he said, "Look at these kimsuka trees, blooming brightly as if adorned by their own flowers. With winter's end, they appear radiant."

He continued, "Behold these bhallataka trees, laden with fruits and leaves. Though there are none to enjoy them, they are abundant and welcoming. Surely, this place is fit for our dwelling."

To Lakshmana, he pointed out, "See the honeycombs hanging like wooden vessels, teeming with bees on every tree. The forest is scattered with fallen flowers where peacocks respond to the calls of the natyuha bird."

The entourage moved forward, encountering flocks of singing birds and herds of elephants as they approached the sacred, level grounds of Chitrakuta. Enthralled by the towering peaks and lush flora, Rama spoke, "This is indeed a delightful forest. Let us enjoy its beauty."

As they reached this enchanting mountain, filled with birds, fruits, roots, and sweet waters, Rama remarked to Lakshmana, "This place is truly a happy abode. Great sages dwell here. Let us call it home."

Proceeding to the hermitage of sage Valmiki, they paid obeisance with folded hands. Delighted, the sage, well-versed in righteousness, welcomed them warmly and invited them to be seated.

Rama, the mighty elder brother, revealed his identity to the sage and then turned to Lakshmana. "O handsome Lakshmana, construct a hut with strong logs," he commanded, "For my heart is set to remain here."

Lakshmana, ever obedient, gathered an assortment of sturdy logs and fashioned a dwelling, securing it with leaves. Rama, pleased with the well-built leaf hut, instructed Lakshmana, "Those wishing to reside here must appease the deity presiding over this place."

Thus, he directed, "Slay an antelope for offering and remember the sacred rites." Lakshmana, dutifully carrying out the task, prepared the venison. Rama expressed his intention to perform the rituals with expertise and reverence.

With Rama reciting mantras proficiently, the offerings to the Vastu devata were made. Rama, purifying himself with a ritual bath and with focused mind, consecrated the hut through prayers and oblations to Visvadevas, Rudra, and Vishnu.

After these sacred rites, Rama, bursting with auspicious qualities, created altars and sacred sites for worship around the hermitage. With offerings of garlands, fruits, roots, and well-cooked venison, the trio, like divine beings entering Sudharma's court, stepped into their charming haven.

In this splendid forest teeming with diverse creatures, under trees adorned with vibrant flowers, Rama, with his senses quieted, found profound happiness. Surrounded by the marvels of Chitrakuta and the serene Malyavati River, he shed the sorrow of his banishment from Ayodhya and embraced joy anew.

Guha lingered by the banks of the Ganga, exchanging words with Sumantra, before he departed with a heavy heart. Sumantra, along with Rama, Lakshmana, and Sita, arrived at the sage Bharadwaja's hermitage in Prayaga. They spent the night there and then continued their journey toward the serene Chitrakuta mountain. 

Upon receiving Rama’s permission to return, Sumantra prepared the finest of horses and set out for Ayodhya, his heart weighed down by sorrow. As he journeyed, he swiftly passed through forests rich with fragrance, crossed clear rivers, and traversed villages and towns, reaching Ayodhya by dusk on the third day. However, the city that greeted him was unlike the bustling one he had left, appearing somber and silent.

Contemplating the silent city, Sumantra pondered deeply, overwhelmed with the thought that the city’s elephants, horses, people, and even its king, might have succumbed to grief over Rama's departure. Driven by fast horses, he entered through the city gate, the streets echoing with silence. Yet, as he advanced, throngs of men emerged, surrounding him with urgent voices, inquiring about Rama's whereabouts. Sumantra explained that he had parted with the noble Rama after crossing the Ganga and had returned at his behest.

On hearing this, the faces of the townsfolk filled with tears, their hearts burdened with the realization that Rama, Lakshmana, and Sita had indeed departed. In anguish, they lamented their fate and voiced their loss at no longer seeing the beloved Rama at significant events and gatherings. Rama, who had been a father to them all, always considering their well-being, was now a memory that pained their souls.

Sumantra, his heart aching, moved steadily toward the palace, encountering wailing women peering through windows and others in marketplaces mourning Rama’s absence. Entering the grounds of king Dasaratha's palace, he found it filled with a grieving populace. Women of the palace, distressed at not seeing Rama, cried out in mourning, their eyes brimming with heartfelt sorrow.

Proceeding further, Sumantra heard the king's wives lamenting the agony of Rama’s exile. He wondered how he could face Kausalya, Rama's mother, overwhelmed by her own grief. Acknowledging the truth in the queens' words, he reassured himself as he advanced through the palace, akin to navigating through a fire of sorrow.

Within the palace's eighth courtyard, Sumantra beheld the forlorn figure of king Dasaratha, pale and consumed by the pain of separation. Approaching with reverence, Sumantra delivered Rama's message faithfully. The king listened in a tormented silence, but soon was overcome with anguish and collapsed.

As Dasaratha fainted, a wail rose from the women within the palace, their cries a torrent of despair. Kausalya, supported by Sumitra, lifted her husband, urging him to rise, to question the charioteer about their son, and not to let grief render him powerless. She implored him to speak freely, as Kaikeyi, the cause of their suffering, was absent.

Overcome with her own sorrow, Kausalya collapsed alongside the king, setting off a lamentation among the royal women. Their cries reached the people outside, drawing the citizens of Ayodhya—old and young, men and women—all of whom joined in a collective, mournful chorus, filling the city with the sounds of a shared sorrow.

Once the king regained his senses, he sought solace and summoned Sumantra, the charioteer, to deliver news of his beloved son, Rama. The charioteer approached with folded palms, his heart heavy with grief, seeing the aged King Dasaratha consumed by sorrow. The king, like a captured, ailing elephant, was lost in thoughts of Rama, sighing deeply.

The dust-covered, tear-streaked king, seeing the charioteer's dejection, addressed him in profound despair. "O charioteer, Rama, righteous and accustomed to every comfort, now seeks refuge beneath trees. How shall he endure? What shall he eat? How can my son, used to a regal bed and undeserving of hardship, sleep on the bare ground like an orphan? How will he fare, having once been followed by elephants, chariots, and soldiers, now alone in the forest's wilds? How will those two young princes and the delicate Sita survive amidst the perilous beasts?

"O Sumantra, you are fortunate to have seen my sons as they entered the forest's edge, like divine Ashwins stepping onto Mandara Mountain. Tell me of their journey—where did Rama sit, sleep, and what sustenance did he find? Your words alone may sustain me, like Yayati among sages."

Sumantra, struggling through his tears, told the king of Rama's parting words. "O great king, with folded palms and bowing head, Rama bade me tell you of his unwavering reverence: 'Convey my salutations to my father, revered for wisdom, and to all the women of the palace, ask after their wellbeing.

“'To my mother, express my regard and counsel her to serve King Dasaratha with reverence, adhering to the righteous path. Let her maintain harmony with all, especially with Kaikeyi. Tell Bharata to honor our mothers equally and fulfil his duties gladly as a prince regent, living joyously under the king's command.'"

Rama's tears flowed as he entreated Sumantra, "Look after my mother as your own." Meanwhile, Lakshmana, burning with anger, questioned the justice of their banishment. "For what misdeed has Rama been sent away? The king, bending to Kaikeyi's whims, has committed an act—just or unjust, he knows alone. Whether driven by greed or obligation to a boon, it is a grave wrong. I see no reason other than delusion or divine fear for Rama's banishment. Rama alone is my brother, guide, and father. Having exiled him, a beacon of righteousness, how can you retain the people's love?

"And Sita, delicate and untested by hardship, stood silent, her mind troubled by sorrow. As I departed, she gazed at Rama, tears marking her pale cheeks. Supported by Lakshmana, Rama stood weeping, hands clasped in farewell, the despondent Sita beside him, lost in grief."

Thus ended Sumantra's heartbreaking account, leaving King Dasaratha to grapple with the weight of his actions, as the tale of Rama's departure unfolded in the pages of their shared destiny.

Upon the request of the king, the noble minister Sumantra, overwhelmed with tears, recounted Rama's parting words. The sorrowful tale began with Rama and his companions clad in simple garb, crossing the sacred Ganga and moving towards Prayaga.

Lakshmana led the way, vigilantly guarding his brother Rama, the pride of the Raghu dynasty, while Sumantra returned to Ayodhya, feeling helpless and abandoned. As he departed, his very horses wept, unwilling to tread the path without their beloved prince.

Despite his grief, Sumantra paid his respects to the departing heroes and ascended his chariot with a heavy heart. Alongside Guha, he lingered in hope, praying for Rama’s recall. Yet days passed with no sign of return.

The once-flourishing kingdom of Ayodhya languished under the weight of Rama’s exile. Trees withered, rivers grew tepid, and the once-vibrant forests lay silent. The natural world itself mourned the absence of Rama, as did the people of the land.

As Sumantra reached Ayodhya, no joyous cries greeted him. The city, draped in sorrow, remained lifeless at the sight of the empty chariot. Women of the palaces, upon noticing Rama's absence, cried out in despair, their tears flowing freely. Their inner turmoil was mirrored in the faces of the townsfolk; friends and strangers alike shared a singular grief.

Even the grand elephants and noble horses appeared dispirited. The city, once vibrant, now resembled the forlorn Kausalya, Rama's heartbroken mother.

Listening to Sumantra’s tale, the king was consumed by anguish. He regretted the hasty decision, incited by Kaikeyi, to send Rama away without consulting wise counsel. His lament attributed the misfortune to the cruel workings of fate.

Desperate to reunite with his son, the king beseeched Sumantra to take him to Rama swiftly, for he felt his life slipping away with every moment of separation. He yearned to see Rama, mighty and noble, alongside his devoted wife Sita.

Dasaratha’s despair deepened as he confessed his impending demise if denied the sight of his son. The king lamented his fate, acknowledging the cruel manipulations of Manthara and the boons granted to Kaikeyi as the source of his suffering.

In a state of pure misery, the king envisioned his sorrow as an ocean, each element of his grief a wave threatening to engulf him. His heartache for Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana was insurmountable, the separation driving him to unconsciousness.

Thus, in the gripping thrall of sorrow, the king succumbed to his despair, leaving the city and its people in unbearable grief.

Kausalya lay trembling on the floor, her grief consuming her as though possessed by some sinister force. Her heart torn, she implored the charioteer, Sumantra, "Take me to where Rama, Sita, and Lakshmana are. I cannot live without them."

Yearning vehemently, she urged him, "Turn your chariot toward the Dandaka forest. If I cannot be with them, I shall not endure even a moment longer in this world."

Sumantra, his heart heavy and words choked with tears, sought to console her. "Restrain your sorrow, noble queen. Rama, with unwavering resolve, embraces the forest, leaving behind all agony."

He spoke of Lakshmana, ever dutiful and steadfast, whose loyalty to Rama was his guiding light. "His devotion secures his place in the next world," he assured her.

Sita, too, he described with reverence, her mind unwaveringly fixed on Rama. "In that desolate wilderness, she finds no fear, as though it were her very home."

Her spirit did not falter, not a trace of melancholy veiled her features. Where once she took joy in Ayodhya's gardens, now the forest brought her delight.

Charming as the full moon, Sita reveled under the forest canopy, her heart tethered to Rama's. "This forest is her paradise, as Ayodhya would be desolate without him," Sumantra explained.

As they journeyed, Sita, ever curious, questioned Rama and Lakshmana about the sights they encountered. The villages, rivers, and trees stirred in her the thrill of a nearby garden excursion.

Sumantra's voice softened, touching on a matter concerning Kaikeyi, though its specifics eluded him now. He gently diverted the conversation to soothe Kausalya's aching heart.

Sita's radiance, he described, remained untouched by the journey's hardships. Her eloquence bloomed like a lotus of a hundred petals, her glow unfaded, sheltering beneath Rama's protection.

Her feet, unadorned, retained the beauty of red lac, and she walked gracefully, accompanied by the melodic chime of her anklets. Fearless she tread, protected by Rama, undaunted by the forest's fierce creatures.

"Do not lament for them, nor for yourself, nor for the king, for this tale of Rama will echo eternally in the world," Sumantra reassured. "They honor their father’s vow, pursuing the path of the great sages with joyful resolve, sustained by nature's bounty."

But Kausalya, despite his comforting words, could not cease her weeping. "O my beloved, O my son, O Rama," she cried, her sorrow unbridled and profound. Thus the account unfolded, a poignant chapter in the timeless saga of the Ramayana.

When Rama, known for his unparalleled devotion to duty, departed for the forest, Kausalya, his mother, was engulfed in sorrow. With tears streaming down her face, she approached her husband, King Dasaratha. She spoke of his widespread fame, celebrated across the three worlds for his compassion, generosity, and gentle speech.

“O Dasaratha,” she lamented, “how will our sons and Sita, raised amidst luxury, endure the harsh forest life? How can Sita, the tender daughter of Mithila, accustomed to comfort, withstand the extremes of heat and cold? The nourishing delights she once enjoyed will be replaced with coarse forest fare. The music of her youth will be drowned by the terrifying sounds of wilderness beasts.”

Kausalya’s grief intensified as she envisioned Rama, her illustrious and mighty son, sleeping on the ground, using his strong arm as a pillow. “When shall I see him again?” she yearned, picturing his lotus-like face, hair, and eyes full of grace. “My heart, it seems, is made of iron, for it does not shatter in this despair of losing sight of my beloved Rama.

“Because of your unfeeling actions, our Rama and our kin, who are destined for joy, now wander the desolate woods. Even if Rama returns after his exile, I fear Bharata will not relinquish the kingdom willingly. It's akin to a feast where one feeds his relations first, leaving only remnants for the Brahmins. Just like the revered Brahmins disdain offerings once others have partaken, so too would Rama disdain a kingdom tainted by another's rule.

“Rama, a tiger among men, will never subsist on the remains of others’ pleasures. Sacrificial offerings cannot be reused, nor can nourishment drained of its essence. Likewise, such a kingdom is unworthy of Rama. His righteous wrath has the power to cleave mountains and bring justice back to this world. Yet, in respect for you, his father, Rama restrains from defiance. The cosmic order holds because of his respect and duty.”

Kausalya continued, her voice filled with mournful conviction. “Rama’s dignity is unyielding. Even against the whole world, he stands fearless, capable of upheaving the very elements themselves. This valiant son, who could consume the universe in fire, has been cast away by his own father, a tragic act likened to a mighty fish devouring its own.

“Your actions have led to the exile of a son devoted to righteousness. Where is the justice in this according to sacred tradition? A woman relies on her husband, her son, and her kin. Now, for me, there remains no solace, no refuge in this world.”

With each word, Kausalya’s sorrow and the depth of her wisdom laid bare the profound injustice of her beloved son’s fate.

In the dimming light of the day, King Dasaratha sat in his chamber, his heart heavy and mind troubled by recent events. The harsh words of Kausalya, his beloved queen, echoed in his ears, compounding his sorrow. The weight of past sins bore down upon him, clouding his senses. He remembered the fateful day of a long-past misdeed, where an errant arrow, guided by sound alone, had led to tragedy. 

As his consciousness returned, Dasaratha’s chest heaved with deep, sorrowful sighs. His eyes, weary with regret, found Kausalya beside him, and a renewed wave of anxiety gripped him. His mind was consumed by remorse for two grievous actions: the unintended slaying of a sage's son and the banishment of his own beloved Rama. These twin sorrows plunged him into a state of trembling despair.

In an effort to soothe his troubled heart, Dasaratha turned to Kausalya, folding his hands in humble entreaty. "O Kausalya," he implored, "be merciful. Your nature is gentle, even toward those who wrong you. In the eyes of righteous women, a husband is a divine figure, virtuous or not. You, who tread always the path of righteousness, know the pain I bear."

Kausalya, touched by the king’s plea and filled with her own sorrow, was moved to tears. Her emotions overwhelmed her as she raised her folded palms to her head, her voice wavering with the weight of her grief. "O lord," she said, "your entreaty wounds me deeply. Yet I have spoken harshly, driven by my grief for our son. Forgive me, for I have erred."

She acknowledged the destructive power of grief, lamenting its ability to obliterate fortitude and shroud the knowledge of sacred teachings. Even the wise and learned, she reflected, are not immune to its delusions. The five nights since Rama's exile felt like five long years, her joy swept away by the flood of sorrow. Her heart swelled with longing for her son, like an ocean rising with the rush of rivers.

Thus, as Kausalya poured out her sorrow, the sun's rays dimmed and the night quietly descended, wrapping the royal chamber in its deep, quiet embrace.

Awakening in deep sorrow, King Dasaratha, like Indra overshadowed by a dark calamity, recalled his past misdeed, which tormented him like the sun obscured during an eclipse. Reflecting on the banishment of his beloved sons, Rama and Lakshmana, he yearned to share the burden of his remorse with Kausalya, his wife.

He pondered over his actions, understanding the inevitability of reaping what one sows. Acknowledging his folly, he lamented his lack of foresight, much like planting fruitless trees expecting a harvest. In his youth, celebrated for his exceptional archery skills, Dasaratha had committed a grievous sin driven by ignorance.

As he recounted to Kausalya, the rainy season had just begun to stir life into its vibrant dance, with the world cooling under the cleansing showers. The rivers, infused with minerals from the rugged mountains, meandered in altered courses, painting the landscape in hues of red and white.

In this enchanting season, Dasaratha set out towards the serene banks of the Sarayu River for a hunt. Concealed by the night, his senses overtaken, he aimed to hunt by sound alone. Amidst the quiet, he heard what seemed the sound of an elephant drinking water. Hastily, he released an arrow, only to realize with dawning horror that he had struck a young ascetic filling his pitcher at the river.

Shocked and trembling, Dasaratha raced to the bank where the ascetic lay, embroiled in pain and defenseless. The ascetic’s cries pierced Dasaratha's heart. Though living an ascetic life, the young man lamented not for his own life, but for his blind and aged parents, now left without support. His voice echoed with distress for his parents, unaware of their son's fate, awaiting his return with water, wrestling against thirst and frailty.

The weight of his action bore heavily upon Dasaratha, who stood on the brink of despair. The dying ascetic urged him to inform his parents, fearing their grief and potential wrath. Instructed to seek forgiveness from the ascetic's father, Dasaratha hesitated over whether to pull the arrow from the youth’s body. The young man, perceiving the king's inner turmoil, reassured him.

In his final moments, the ascetic revealed that he was not a Brahmin, but born of mixed caste. This revelation eased Dasaratha's conscience slightly, but the pain of the unintended tragedy lingered. With this burden on his heart, Dasaratha's anguish remained a poignant testament to the consequences of heedless actions.

In the silence of his chamber, King Dasaratha, the noble and righteous descendant of the Raghus, unfolded a haunting tale to Queen Kausalya, burdened with grief from an ancient sin. He recounted a time when, in youthful folly, he had gravely erred, inadvertently killing a sage's son.

He remembered how his heart was tormented, searching desperately for atonement. Guided by the echoes of his guilt, he followed a path with a pot of pure water, arriving at the dwelling of the boy's blind, elderly parents. Helpless they sat, like birds robbed of flight, speaking tenderly of the son who was their sole support, the very hope he had taken from them.

Grief-stricken, he approached them, only to hear the father's anxious voice calling for his son, unaware of the tragedy. The sage implored his son to return quickly, unaware that the only sound to answer was that of the king's trembling confession.

With words stumbling from his lips and shame filling his heart, Dasaratha revealed the calamity. He had taken his bow to the riverbank, aiming at what he thought was an elephant but striking instead the young ascetic. As the noble youth lay dying, pierced by the arrow, Dasaratha had pulled it out as instructed, hearing the boy’s final, pained whispers of the blind parents who depended on him.

The sage, stunned by the revelation of his son's death, was overwhelmed with sorrow. He lamented, his grief a mirror of Dasaratha’s own, tearing through the quiet air. The boy’s parents yearned for one last look at their beloved son, hoping to find some solace beside his still form, draped in the garments of ascetic life, now spattered with blood.

Dasaratha gently led them to the tragic scene. The bereaved parents collapsed beside their son, pouring out their hearts in heartrending cries. They mourned his silence, longed for his tender voice, and despaired at the void left by his absence.

As their tears flowed, the young sage’s spirit, ascending to heaven, reassured his grieving parents that they too would join him in blessed realms. The funeral rites were performed with due sanctity, and the celestial chariot bore their virtuous son to the heavens, leaving a painful, empty silence behind.

In a solemn voice, the father turned to Dasaratha, demanding retribution—not of earthly vengeance, but the justice only fate could fulfill. He declared that just as the king had unknowingly severed their bond, he would face a similar torment: to be torn from his beloved son, Rama.

The sage laid a curse upon Dasaratha, yet acknowledged that the monarch had not acted with malicious intent, sparing him immediate divine repercussions. Having spoken, the sorrowful couple joined their son in the afterlife, united in their departure.

As Dasaratha recounted this tale to Kausalya, the weight of that bygone sin pressed heavily upon him. Now, as the prophetic words of the sage came to pass, he felt life slipping away, shadows dimming his sight. Haunted by the separation from Rama, his heart wilted, much like parched earth under a relentless sun.

Yearning for a final glimpse of his exiled son, the king's spirit faded. His thoughts wove between cherished memories and the realization that soon he would meet Yama, the lord of death. With the last wisps of breath, he lamented over the causes of his despair, from the betrayal that had set these events in motion to the blessed return he longed but now would never witness.

Thus, the mighty King Dasaratha succumbed to grief, his noble heart stilled by the sorrow of Rama's absence, lamented by Kausalya and Sumitra. His life ebbed away with the night, a melancholy end for a king once bound in glory but now undone by love’s deepest wound.

As dawn broke, panegyrists, bards, and genealogists arrived at the palace, their voices rich with benedictions and songs lauding King Dasaratha's illustrious reign. Their harmonious melodies filled the air, resonating through the corridors, as they clapped and recounted the king's noble deeds. Even the palace birds, perched on branches and housed in gilded cages, awoke to join the chorus with their delicate trills.

The sacred hymns, accompanied by the gentle strumming of veenas, wove an atmosphere of reverence throughout the royal abode. Meanwhile, devoted attendants gathered, observing their ceremonial duties, bringing with them water infused with yellow sandalwood paste in golden vessels, and auspicious unguents carried by a procession of young maidens. They prepared eagerly, waiting to assist the king in his morning rituals.

As the sun crept higher, an uneasy doubt settled among the waiting attendants—King Dasaratha had not appeared. The time-honored rituals remained incomplete, and concern grew. The maidservants, familiar with their sovereign's private chambers, approached in hopes of rousing him from slumber. Yet their gentle calls met with unsettling silence.

Carefully, they touched his bed, skilled as they were in discerning the nature of sleep from the usual signs, but no sign of life could be perceived. Their hearts began to beat in uncertainty, shaken like reeds against a relentless current.

Venturing closer, they were confronted with the inevitable truth: the king had departed from the mortal world. Anxiety gripped their hearts, confirming their worst fears, and a wave of sorrow engulfed them.

Queens Kausalya and Sumitra, overwhelmed by grief for their sons, had fallen into a deep, mournful sleep, unaware of their lord's passing. Kausalya lay upon the floor, fatigued and tarnished by despair, resembling stars veiled by a heavy darkness.

Despite their sorrowful state, the mournful cries of the other women penetrated the queens’ slumber. Awakened, they reached for their beloved Dasaratha, only to discover the lifeless form of their husband. Stricken with grief, Kausalya cried out and fell to the ground, her tears mingling with the dust upon her face.

The sight of Dasaratha's still body plunged the entire assembly into further despair. Led by Kaikeyi, the king's wives succumbed to their sorrow, collapsing in a tumult of tears and lament. Their wails echoed through the palace, amplifying until the very walls seemed to tremble with shared grief.

The realization of Dasaratha's passing spread quickly, erasing all remnants of joy from the palace. Bewildered and frightened, the people gathered, their hearts heavy with anguish. The cries of the mourners became a mournful chorus that enveloped the royal residence, casting a shadow of deep mourning over all.

Thus, the majestic abode of Ayodhya, which once brimmed with life and prosperity, now lay shrouded in a palpable sadness, as the kingdom mourned the loss of its noble king. The grieving queens encircled their fallen lord, clinging to one another in their heartbreak, their lamentations resonating like a forlorn symphony.

As King Dasaratha ascended to the heavenly realms, his departure felt like a sudden extinguishing of a blazing fire or an ocean emptied of water. Kausalya, overwhelmed with sorrow, gently raised the king’s head onto her lap, her eyes brimming with tears. She looked at Kaikeyi, her countenance marked by grief.
